description: From Middle English seem, seme, from Old English sēam (“seam”), from Proto-West Germanic *saum, from Proto-Germanic *saumaz (“that which is sewn”).

entries.meaning: (sewing) A folded-back and stitched piece of fabric; especially, the stitching that joins two or more pieces of fabric.
(geology) A thin stratum, especially of an economically viable material such as coal or mineral.
(cricket) The stitched equatorial seam of a cricket ball; the sideways movement of a ball when it bounces on the seam.
(construction, nautical) A joint formed by mating two separate sections of materials.
examples: Seams can be made or sealed in a variety of ways, including adhesive bonding, hot-air welding, solvent welding, using adhesive tapes, sealant, etc.

entries.meaning: A line or depression left by a cut or wound; a scar; a cicatrix.
(figurative) A line of junction; a joint.
examples: Precepts should be so finely wrought together […] that no coarse seam may discover where they join.

verbs.description: seam (third-person singular simple present seams, present participle seaming, simple past and past participle seamed)

entries.meaning: To put together with a seam.
examples: Thus, seamed with many scars, / Bursting these prison bars, / Up to its native stars / My soul ascended!

entries.meaning: To make the appearance of a seam in, as in knitting a stocking; hence, to knit with a certain stitch, like that in such knitting.
To mark with a seam or line; to scar.
To crack open along a seam.
examples: Later their lips began to parch and seam.

entries.meaning: (cricket) Of the ball, to move sideways after bouncing on the seam.
(cricket) Of a bowler, to make the ball move thus.

description: From Old English sēam (“a burden”), from Latin sagma (“saddle”).

entries.meaning: (historical) An old English measure of grain, containing eight bushels.
(historical) An old English measure of glass, containing twenty-four weys of five pounds, or 120 pounds.
examples: As white glass was 6s. the 'seam', containing 24 'weys' (pise, or pondera) of 5 lb., and 2½ lb. was reckoned sufficient to make one foot of glazing, the cost of glass would be 1½d. leaving 2½d. for labour.

description: From Middle English seym (“grease”), from Old French saim (“fat”). Compare French saindoux (“lard”).
